Location:
Sunset Cay Marina (Folly Beach, South Carolina)
Description
 Work outdoors in Charleston, SC exploring the beautiful waterways surrounding Folly Beach! We are seeking part-time boat captains to lead eco-tours for the 2026 season.

Key Responsibilities:
Captain 24ft/12pax & 28ft/18pax Carolina Skiffs
Lead 2 & 3 hour eco tours for a variety of audiences
Participate in training prior to your first solo tour
Display excellent customer-service skills when working with guests
Safely operate and navigate vessels
Provide engaging, educational commentary about the local wildlife, marine ecosystems, and local history.
Conduct pre- and post-trip inspections of the vessel.
Perform daily maintenance like refueling, cleaning, and other light maintenance tasks. Communicate larger maintenance needs promptly and assist as needed.
Comply with all U.S. Coast Guard regulations and company safety protocols.

Required Qualifications:
Active Masters USCG license required.
CPR/First Aid/Lifeguard certification (we will provide recertification if necessary).
Ability to lift at least 50 lbs and perform physical tasks associated with boat operations.
Ability to work outdoors in all weather conditions, including extreme heat and humidity
Willingness to work evenings and weekends.
Experience with public speaking.
Excellent customer service and people skills.
Must be reliable, professional, and able to remain calm and adaptable in stressful circumstances.

Preferred Qualifications:
Preference will be given to candidates who have experience with trailering, boat maintenance, and/or working with children.
Knowledge of local waterways, wildlife, and environmental issues is highly preferred (education or hands-on work experience).
Work Schedule: This is a part-time, seasonal role with hours/scheduling flexible for the right candidate. The busiest season is Memorial Day to Labor Day, but we operate regularly from March-November. Tours operate 7 days a week and include late evening sunset trips.

Compensation: Competitive hourly rate plus tips. Training pay is $20/hr and will go up after training period commensurate with performance and experience. Our Captains average ~$40/hour including tips.

Benefits:
Use of kayaks and paddling equipment
Free seats on boat tours when available
Pro deals on national outdoor brands

How to Apply: Please submit a resume and a short introduction to saltmarshadventure@gmail.com. Please include “Part-time Captain Application” in the subject line.

About Tideline Tours: Tideline Tours is a eco-tourism company based in Folly Beach, South Carolina. We specialize in outdoor education, although we offer a wide range of tour options including dolphin tours, fossil hunting, kayaking, culinary tours, and special events like bachelorette parties and kids' programs. For more information about our tours and company, visit our website: www.tidelinetours.com .

Job Types: Part-time, Contract, Temporary

Benefits:
Employee discount
Flexible schedule
Professional development assistance

License/Certification:
USCG Master License (Required)
Lifeguard, CPR, First Aid (we will provide training if needed)
Contact
Olivia DePue
saltmarshadventure@gmail.com (preferred contact method)

title: PhD assistantship: Rio Grande cutthroat trout conservation and genetics

PhD assistantship: Rio Grande cutthroat trout conservation and genetics
New Mexico State University (State)
Details

8/17/2026

at least 20

$28,384 to $29,041 per year
Education Required:
Bachelors
Experience Required:
none
Location:
New Mexico State University (Las Cruces, New Mexico)
Tags:
Graduate Opportunities
Description
RIO GRANDE CUTTHROAT TROUT PHD ASSISTANTSHIP

Description & project background: 

The Pregler Lab at New Mexico State University in the Department of Fish, Wildlife, and Conservation Ecology invites applications for a PhD research assistantship focused on Rio Grande cutthroat trout conservation. The successful applicant will begin in the Fall 2026 semester.

Rio Grande cutthroat trout (RGCT) are the southernmost species of cutthroat trout and have experienced a severe decline in both range and abundance, now occupying only ~12 percent of its historical distribution and requires targeted management interventions to support recovery. Major components of the recovery plan detail the need to secure extant populations and reintroduce individuals within their native range in Colorado and New Mexico. Recent efforts to date include development of a multi-source, genetically diverse broodstock for the Rio Grande basin that is used for reintroduction efforts.

Individuals from this multi-source broodstock were stocked at multiple sites throughout the recently restored Rio Costilla watershed which represents one of the largest native fish restoration projects in the country. While recent research has shown that this composite broodstock is more genetically diverse compared to using single source populations there is a need to evaluate how these fish are performing in the wild. The present project has a number of goals:

          1. Evaluate genetic structure and diversity of reintroduced Rio Costilla RGCT populations
                     a. There is also opportunity to develop questions with demographic monitoring data in this system.
          2. Genetic assessment of Rio Grande, Canadian, and Pecos basins. 
                     a. Results will help inform multi-source broodstock development for Canadian & Pecos basins and identify additional source populations for Rio Grande basin.
                     b. Results will also provide an updated genetic assessment for RGCT.
          3. There are additional opportunities for the student to develop their own questions using genetic and demographic data.

This project is a collaborative effort funded by the New Mexico Department of Wildlife and there may be potential to collaborate with other university researchers and agencies. Benefits include a salary range of ~$28-29k/year, full tuition waiver, and subsidized health insurance. Funding will also be available for conference travel, workshop training for data analyses, and safety training (e.g., wilderness first aid). The hired candidate will begin in Fall 2026 and will be based at NMSU in Las Cruces, NM.

How to apply: If interested, please compile the following: (1) a statement of interest that describes your educational and research background, as well as your research interests and how this position fits in your career goals (2) curriculum vitae or resume, (3) contact information for three professional references, and (4) unofficial transcripts compiled in a single PDF and save as ‘Lastname_RGCT_PhD.pdf’.  Applicants are also asked to upload a writing sample in the application portal. Applications should be submitted through the airtable linked here:  https://airtable.com/app3jNqbQZsYstwx7/pagrpU5GqaI6FnSTg/form 

Applications are due 03/18/26 by 11:59p MT. You can learn more about the Pregler Lab at https://preglerlab.com and any questions about the position can be sent to Dr. Kasey Pregler at kpregler@nmsu.edu.   

Qualifications: 

Required: B.S. in fisheries, biology, or related field and possession of a valid U.S. driver’s license. The successful applicant must also meet the minimum requirements for admission to the NMSU Graduate School (3.0 GPA in last two years of undergrad). Applicants should also have demonstrated excellent written and oral communication skills, and an ability to work independently. 

Preference will be given to applicants with an M.S. degree in fisheries, biology, or related field and have experience working in the backcountry and are willing to lead field work crews in backcountry conditions.

Successful candidates will have proficiency in R, and an interest in genetics and working with large datasets. They should also demonstrate the ability to work as part of a team and have a willingness to lead field work crews in remote backcountry locations. Applicants with experience in fish ecology, statistical & genetic analysis, and hierarchical modeling are encouraged to apply.  

Salary: 

~$28-29k /year
Full tuition waiver 
Subsidized health insurance

Contact
Kasey Pregler
kpregler@nmsu.edu (preferred contact method)

description:

Colorado State University (State) | https://colostate.edu

Tags:
Graduate Opportunities
Description
A graduate assistantship for a master’s student is expected to be funded at Colorado State University (Fort Collins, CO) working with Dr. Brian D. Gerber (https://bgerber123.github.io/) at the Colorado Cooperative Fish and Wildlife Research Unit and wildlife researchers at Colorado Parks and Wildlife. The graduate research assistantship will cover university tuition, fees, health coverage, and includes a pre-tax monthly pay of $3000/month. The position is expected to start Fall 2026 and be funded through December 2028.

Study Context: Sex and age class are important demographic parameters used in population modeling, in which the results help guide management decisions and annual harvest quotas of large mammals (e.g., elk, bighorn sheep, pronghorn, mule deer). This work will help develop new methodology and workflows that will aid Colorado Parks and Wildlife’s objective of producing robust empirical demographic data and population estimates for harvested wildlife. 

Focus: The focus of this study will be to collect data on the size distribution of elk sex and age classes (cow, calf, bull) to train and test a predictive approach using AI algorithms (developed by Colorado Parks and Wildlife) to classify animals from high-resolution aerial imagery. Field observations and size measurements (via 3D camera) will be collected to help test the accuracy of AI predictions. An additional avenue of exploration may be data collection and AI classification of sex/age class from camera trap images. The student will be expected to develop a project proposal outlining study objectives in coordination with Colorado Parks and Wildlife and a graduate committee at Colorado State University. The student will focus on technological and software workflows to meet study objectives, however, there will likely be field work opportunities as well (e.g., field observations, drone/aerial surveys). Given the trajectory of the wildlife field, the skills gained in this study will likely be desirable for future employers. 

 Preferred Qualifications: 

-          Ungulate field research experience in the intermountain west
-          Clear interest or experience developing data analysis workflows
-          Clear interest or experience advancing technological innovation (hardware/software) in wildlife science
-          Experience deploying camera traps and managing large data sets
-          Experience with AI algorithms, for example MegaDetector or SpeciesNet
 
Minimum Qualifications:
-          A Bachelor of Science degree in wildlife ecology, biology, natural resource management, or related field
-          A year or more of wildlife related professional research/work experience
-          Strong writing skills
-          Strong work ethic 
-          Desire to collaborate with state wildlife management agencies

To be considered, please send the following materials via email with “AI/Elk Application” as the subject line to Dr. Brian D. Gerber (brian.gerber@colostate.edu) by March 2, 2026: 1) Cover letter outlining career goals, academic interests, and relevant experience related to the minimum and preferred qualifications, 2) resume with contact information for 3-4 personal references, and unofficial copy of B.S. transcripts. 

Contact
Brian D. Gerber
brian.gerber@colostate.edu (preferred contact method)

Oregon Institute of Technology (State) | https://www.oit.edu/

between 6/12/2028 and 8/1/2028

6 - 40

starting at $18 per hour
Education Required:
Bachelors

at least 2 years
Location:
Oregon Tech (Klamath Falls, Oregon)
Tags:
Graduate Opportunities
Description
ROJECT TITLE: Pinyon Jay response to juniper management, Deschutes County, Oregon.

BACKGROUND: Pinyon Jays (PIJA, Gymnorhinus cyanocephalus) have experienced significant, range-wide declines over the past 50 years, and are currently under Status Review for ESA listing. Deschutes County, Oregon represents the northwestern-most extent of the species range and lies far outside the extant range of pinyon pine species. Extensive treatments of juniper woodlands have been expedited throughout western states for restoration of sagebrush ecosystems, sage grouse habitat, and altered fire regimes. However, we lack clear understanding of how these treatments impact PIJA populations.  

Management priorities for PIJA in Oregon include assessing impacts of juniper treatments on PIJA and determining state-wide distribution. The primary goals of this project are to experimentally study how juniper treatments impact occupancy, habitat use, and nesting of PIJA on BLM lands in Deschutes County, Oregon. We are implementing a before-after-control-impact study and use bioacoustics monitoring, point counts, and nest searching methods. The MS project will focus on at least one component of the project. This work is in partnership with the East Cascades Bird Alliance, US Fish and Wildlife, and Deschutes BLM. We also contribute to the PIJA Western Working Group and the PIJA Conservation Action Strategy (CAS). The MS candidate will be expected to coordinate with and contribute findings to larger range-wide intiatives. 

LOCATION & PROGRAM: This position supports a student in the Masters of Science in Natural Resources at Oregon Tech in Klamath Falls, OR. Our MS program started in 2024 and is in the Natural Sciences Department, which also encompasses the MS of Medical Science program, and BS programs in Environmental Science and Biology-Health Science. Program description and requirements are here https://www.oit.edu/academics/degrees/natural-resources 

SUPPORT: This position includes the opportunity for a Graduate Teaching Assistantship for the Academic Years 2026-2026 and 2027-2028. The GTA will teach labs in the 200-level Principles of Biology series for majors, &/or similar courses within the students expertise. GTAs cover two 3-hour sections per term. Oregon Tech is on a quarter system. Fall, Winter, and Spring terms are 11 weeks. Our academic year runs from mid-September to Mid-June.  The GTA provides a per-term stipend and partial tuition remission during the academic year (Fall through Spring terms). In addition, this research assistantship will provide additional part-time stipend during the spring term, and full-time hourly salary over the summer. Some travel costs from Klamath Falls to Bend, OR will be covered. The graduate student will be expected to use their own vehicle, preferably one that can handle rugged, rocky roads to access field sites. If the student would prefer to forgo the GTA position and cover their own academic costs, that would be an option. 

POSITION REQUIREMENTS: The candidate should have a Bachelors degree in Natural Resources, Wildlife, Ecology, Environmental Science or a closely related program of study and should meet the requirements for acceptance into the Masters of Natural Resources program at Oregon Tech. Ideally, the applicant will have at least 2 years of field experience studying birds, particularly nest searching and point counts. Experience with bioacoustics monitoring (ARUs, BirdNET) will be especially helpful. Additionally, experience doing habitat analyses (Occupancy modeling, RSFs, SDMs) using program R and GIS will be very valuable.  The candidate should have proven ability to work independently in remote areas, and as a member of a team, including supervising undergraduates and working with volunteers. 

 

DATES: Start date is flexible. We are beginning the greater project design and implementation this winter 2026, therefore, the candidate could start as early as March, 2026 as a temporary hire. The academic year begins in mid-September, 2026. 

LOCATION: Oregon Tech is in Klamath Falls, OR, a small rural region of south-central Oregon. The field research about 3 hours north, near Bend and Sisters, Oregon in the east Cascades, sage-steppe biome. This region is famous for its scenic beauty, biodiversity, and outdoor recreation including hiking and trail running, mountain biking, skiing, and water sports.  

APPLICATIONS: Please email a cover letter detailing your experience, interest in the project, and career goals, along with your CV to Jherime.kellermann@oit.edu ASAP.  We will review packages as they are received.

Contact
Jherime Kellermann
5418515156
jherime.kellermann@oit.edu (preferred contact method)

Description
PhD Scholarship
Transforming Climate Action – Uncertain Seas 
 
A PhD Scholarship is available at the Centre for Fisheries Ecosystems Research, Fisheries & Marine Institute, Memorial University, St. John’s, NL, Canada.

Transforming Climate Action is a seven year, $397 million collaboration among Dalhousie University, Laval University, University Québec at Rimouski, and Memorial University. The largest research theme within Transforming Climate Action is Reducing Uncertainties in Carbon Cycling in the Northwest Atlantic Seas (Uncertain Seas). The goal of Uncertain Seas is to better constrain the role of the ocean in the Earth’s climate system by reducing uncertainties with physical and biogeochemical processes that control the global ocean carbon cycle. The focus is on the Northwest Atlantic gateway as a major contributor to ocean carbon uptake and sequestration, particularly with respect to the biological carbon pump.
We are seeking a PhD Student to estimate carbon fluxes in the Northwest Atlantic from Earth system and ecosystem models. As a part of Transforming Climate Action, there will be opportunities to participate in workshops with other graduate students from the four institutions. There will also be opportunities for research visits to collaborating labs and conference travel. There may be opportunities to participate in research expeditions, although not a requirement.  

Location: The student will be enrolled in the PhD in Fisheries Science graduate program at the Fisheries & Marine Institute, Memorial University, in St. John’s, NL, Canada.  Memorial University is a hub of ocean sciences located in the Province’s capital. St. John’s is a safe and friendly city with great historical charm, known for its hospitality, live music, a vibrant cultural life, and easy access to wilderness and a wide range of outdoor activities.

Requirements: 
 MSc or equivalent in Fisheries Science, Ecology, Statistics, Mathematics, Marine Ecology, Biology, Oceanography or related discipline 
 Demonstrated quantitative skills in ecosystem and/or statistical modelling
 Strong writing and communication skills

Start date: Flexible, ideally September 1, 2026

Stipend: $30K/year for four years

To apply: Please send a cover letter explaining your relevant experience to, and interest in, the project, CV with academic references (contact information, reference letters not required), and university transcripts to Dr. Tyler Eddy tyler.eddy@mi.mun.ca. If you have an interest in one of the four project areas, please elaborate in your cover letter.

Application deadline: Applications will be reviewed as received. To ensure that your application is given priority consideration, apply by May 31, 2026.
Contact
Tyler Eddy
tyler.eddy@mi.mun.ca (preferred contact method)

title: Graduate Assistantship at WVU: Aquatic Species Responses to Changing River Conditions
description:
Graduate Assistantship at WVU: Aquatic Species Responses to Changing River Conditions
Aquatic lab- West Virginia University (Private)
Details
Application Deadline:
04/01/2026
Published:
02/13/2026

8/17/2026
Hours per Week:
at least 40

$21,000 to $27,000 per year
Education Required:
Bachelors
Experience Required:
at least 2 years
Location:
West Virginia University (Morgantown, West Virginia)
Tags:
Graduate Opportunities
Description
The Davis College of Agriculture, Natural Resources, and Design at West Virginia University, through Dr. Carol Arantes’s lab, is recruiting a Master’s or PhD student to begin in Fall 2026 to study how changes in river conditions affect aquatic ecosystems and biodiversity. 

The student will be part of a collaborative, interdisciplinary project examining how global hydraulic infrastructure and river management over the past century have altered river discharge regimes and aquatic ecosystems, and how uncertainty in reconstructed historical records affects confidence in global assessments of river change. Working within a multi-institutional research team, the student will collaborate closely with a modeling group to develop and apply new models and indicators of river processes that integrate hydrologic alteration, river fragmentation, sediment transport, river temperature, and patterns of fish diversity and abundance. 

The student will work closely with the PI, postdoctoral researchers, and a multi-institutional team of project partners to integrate ecological data with large-scale environmental and infrastructure datasets. Expected outcomes include peer-reviewed publications, technical reports, and presentations for both scientific and non-scientific audiences. The position offers strong training opportunities in quantitative analysis, interdisciplinary research, and professional development. 

Qualifications 
Applicants must hold a B.S. or M.S. degree in ecology, fisheries, zoology, aquatic sciences, or a closely related field, with a minimum GPA of 3.0/4.0. Successful candidates will demonstrate strong written and oral communication skills, solid analytical abilities, and the capacity to work independently and collaboratively. Experience or strong interest in fish and aquatic ecology is required. Experience with or interest in computer modeling, statistical analysis (Bayesian and/or frequentist approaches), and GIS is highly desirable. 

 Funding:
The selected student will be supported through a combination of Teaching Assistantships (TAships) and Research Assistantships (RAships), for a total of three years of funding.

M.S. students will receive a stipend of $21,000 per year plus a full tuition waiver.

Ph.D. students will receive 9 months of funding per year plus a full tuition waiver, with opportunities for additional summer salary contingent upon successful completion of stream surveys and project fieldwork.

 How to Apply
Interested students should email the following materials as a single PDF directly to:
Dr. Carol Arantes
caroline.arantes@mail.wvu.edu 

Application materials should include: 

A brief cover letter describing research background, interests, career goals, and motivation for pursuing an MS or PhD
A current CV or résumé
Names and contact information for three professional references
Unofficial transcripts and GRE scores (if available)

 Please do not submit materials to the WVU Graduate School at this stage.

Additional Information
 Davis College of Agriculture, Natural Resources, and Design
 https://www.davis.wvu.edu/
School of Natural Resources and the Environment
https://www.davis.wvu.edu/schools/natural-resources-and-the-environment
Dr. Arantes’s lab
https://www.davis.wvu.edu/faculty-staff/directory/carol-arantes
https://aranteslab.weebly.com/ 

 


  Contact
Caroline C. Arantes
caroline.arantes@mail.wvu.edu (preferred contact method)

title: USDA-ARS Sensors for Crops Mortality and Soil Quality in Agriculture Fellowship
description:
USDA-ARS Sensors for Crops Mortality and Soil Quality in Agriculture Fellowship
Oak Ridge Associated Universities (ORAU) (Private) | https://orise.orau.gov/index.html
Details
Posting:
https://www.zintellect.com/Opportunity/Details/USDA-ARS-MWA-2026-0061

04/10/2026
Published:
02/10/2026
Starting Date:
after 2/28/2026
Hours per Week:
at least 40
Salary:
Commensurate / Negotiable
Education Required:
Masters
Experience Required:
none
Location:
Ames, Iowa
Tags:
Graduate Opportunities
Description
 *Applications are reviewed on a rolling-basis.

ARS Office/Lab and Location: A research opportunity is currently available with the U.S. Department of Agriculture (USDA), Agricultural Research Service (ARS), located in Ames, Iowa.

The Agricultural Research Service (ARS) is the U.S. Department of Agriculture's chief scientific in-house research agency with a mission to find solutions to agricultural problems that affect Americans every day from field to table. ARS will deliver cutting-edge, scientific tools and innovative solutions for American farmers, producers, industry, and communities to support the nourishment and well-being of all people; sustain our nation’s agroecosystems and natural resources; and ensure the economic competitiveness and excellence of our agriculture. The vision of the agency is to provide global leadership in agricultural discoveries through scientific excellence.

The National Laboratory for Agriculture and the Environment (NLAE) generates information addressing critical problems in agriculture and watershed management to develop innovative solutions which increase the efficiency of agriculture systems and reduce environmental risk. Transdisciplinary teams address this through coordinated research in abiotic and biotic systems.

Research Project:  Under the guidance of a mentor, the fellow will have the opportunity to participate in a project that address the challenges crop producers in the US Midwest region face with associated losses of nutrients and nutrient use efficiency all of which affect crop productivity and mortality. This research will help close the nitrogen balance through careful measurements of N inputs and N outputs under different treatments and weather conditions. The research will utilize graphene sensors to measure N losses through the soil for the different treatments.  Complementary measurements of crop leaf area index during the lifecycle of the crop will be taken.

Learning Objectives: 

Learn about nitrogen inputs
Learn about fertilizer input/outputs
Learn on how to draft technical articles
Learn skills in collaboration
Mentor(s): The mentor for this opportunity is Thanos Papanicolaou (thanos.papanicolaou@usda.gov). If you have questions about the nature of the research, please contact the mentor(s).

Anticipated Appointment Start Date: February 2026. Start date is flexible and will depend on a variety of factors.

Appointment Length: The appointment will initially be for one year, but may be renewed upon recommendation of ARS and is contingent on the availability of funds.

Level of Participation: The appointment is full time.

Participant Stipend: The participant will receive a monthly stipend commensurate with educational level and experience. The anticipated stipend range is $3,500 - $3,800 monthly.

Citizenship Requirements: This opportunity is available to U.S. citizens only.

ORISE Information: This program, administered by ORAU through its contract with the U.S. Department of Energy (DOE) to manage the Oak Ridge Institute for Science and Education (ORISE), was established through an interagency agreement between DOE and ARS. Participants do not become employees of USDA, ARS, DOE or the program administrator, and there are no employment-related benefits. Proof of health insurance is required for participation in this program. Health insurance can be obtained through ORISE.

Questions: Please visit our Program Website. After reading, if you have additional questions about the application process, please email ORISE.ARS.Midwest@orau.org and include the reference code for this opportunity.

Qualifications
The qualified candidate should be currently pursuing a master's or doctoral degree in the one of the relevant fields. Degree must be anticipated to be receive by 6/1/2026.

Preferred skills:

Experience in developing ion-selective electrode (ISE) sensors for real-time nutrient monitoring

Funding in anticipated for Graduate Assistantship at the MS (2 years) or PhD (3 years) level in the School of Natural Resources at the University of Tennessee, beginning August 2026, to work on projects in conservation social science. Applicants should hold a degree in wildlife, forestry, natural resources, environmental science, ecology, geography, agricultural economics or a closely related field.

The research will focus on economics, policy, or other social science dimensions of conservation depending upon the interest and background of the student. Description
Description:
Recent advances in virtual fencing (VF) technology are creating new opportunities to transform grazing management and livestock production systems across the western United States. We seek a highly motivated PhD student to contribute to the University of Arizona’s virtual fence research initiative focusing on animal welfare. The successful candidate will lead research looking at seasonal and reproductive-stage differences in grazing behavior, as well as cattle stress and welfare responses associated with interactions with the Halter virtual fencing system in Arizona. This knowledge generated will inform best practices for VF adoption by beef cattle producers in the western U.S. 
 The student will be advised by Flavie Audoin and will be enrolled in the Ecology, Management, and Restoration of Rangelands program within the School of Natural Resources & the Environment (https://snre.arizona.edu/).

Required Qualifications:
- Hold a MS degree in animal sciences, natural resources, or related field.
- Interest in beef cattle physiology, extensive grazing systems, rangeland ecology, animal behavior, animal welfare, or precision livestock technologies.
- Demonstrated diligence and strong work ethic.
- Ability to work independently and collectively as part of an interdisciplinary team.
 Preferred Qualifications:
- Experience with statistical software and analysis as well as data management.
- Large livestock animal experience and laboratory training.
- Strong oral and written communication skills.
 Salary & Benefits: 
Academic and summer compensation available for 5 years [combination of RA and TAships ~ $30K] 
Health insurance, ERE and tuition are provided.

Application Instructions:
1-    A cover letter.
2-    Curriculum Vitae / Resume.
3-    Unofficial or official university transcripts.
4-    Contact information for 3 references.
  Contact
Flavie Audoin

Description
We are pleased to announce that applications are open for the Aquaculture Experiential Opportunities for Undergraduate Students (AquEOUS) Fellowship, an USDA Research and Extension Experience for Undergraduates (REEU) at the University of Maine's Wabanaki Center and Aquaculture Research Institute (ARI) and in collaboration with Wabanaki Youth in Science. 

This unique fellowship offers undergraduate students from around the nation an opportunity to use indigenous science and STEM concepts to solve real-world problems in aquaculture at the University of Maine’s world class aquaculture facilities. Mentorship will be provided by interdisciplinary faculty and indigenous knowledge keepers.

Through this paid fellowship, students will have an array of research foci from which to choose. They will work on hands-on projects using concepts learned from their mentors as well as seminars, field trips, and workshops addressing indigenous knowledge, applied aquaculture science and science communications. a $6,000 stipend plus room and board are provided at the Darling Marine Center in Walpole, ME for 10 weeks. 

We invite students and faculty to learn more about the Aquaculture Experiential Opportunities for Undergraduate Students (AquEOUS) Fellowship and apply by February 22nd. Please feel free to share with anyone who may be interested in this unique program. 

If you have any questions or need additional information, please do not hesitate to contact us directly at ari@maine.edu.

Link to AquEOUS application page: https://umaine.edu/aquaculture/education/4701-2/

Description
Executive Director – Merry Lea Environmental Learning Center (Goshen College)
Goshen College seeks an Executive Director to lead the vision, operations, and growth of Merry Lea Environmental Learning Center in alignment with the college’s Christian, Anabaptist-Mennonite values and commitment to justice, peace, sustainability, and inclusion.

The Executive Director provides overall leadership for educational programming, strategic planning, budgeting, staffing, and long-term financial sustainability. This role oversees all personnel, manages the annual budget, works closely with the Merry Lea Board of Trustees, and represents Merry Lea to the campus, community, faith-based, and national audiences.

Key responsibilities include advancing fundraising and grant efforts in coordination with Goshen College, cultivating donor relationships, leading capital campaigns, and promoting Merry Lea through communications and public engagement. The Executive Director also collaborates with academic departments—especially Biology—to support teaching, research, enrollment goals, and partnerships with other institutions. Depending on qualifications, the role may include a faculty appointment.

Qualifications: A master’s degree in a related environmental field and at least five years of nonprofit executive leadership are required; a doctoral degree, teaching experience, and a strong fundraising record are preferred. The position requires strong communication, financial, and leadership skills, regular on-site presence, some evening/weekend work, and the ability to work both indoors and outdoors in a natural setting.

Contact
Merry Lea
2607995869
merrylea@goshen.edu

Location:
Indiana State University (TERRE HAUTE, Indiana)
Tags:
Graduate Opportunities
Description
Indiana State University Department of Biology is seeking graduate applications (PhD preferred) from highly motivated and capable students to study water snake ecology (diamondback, copperbelly, and common water snakes). This position’s research will build off of a current MS water snake project at Indiana State University that is studying distribution, status, and aspects of niche partitioning.
 A position supported by a teaching assistantship (5 of years of support for PhD; $13,500/year + tuition waiver) will be available starting August 2026. Additional summer assistantships may be available.
 There is opportunity for highly motivated and capable students to develop their own projects based on their interests and skills. Other current lab projects include comparing non-invasive monitoring methods, raccoon parasites, and analysis of stress hormones and ecological contaminants in bats and large carnivores. Graduate research projects can combine traditional field ecology studies with techniques and technology such as ecotoxicology, hormone analysis, GIS habitat analysis, mark-recapture, telemetry, and/or genetics/genomics.  Field-based data collection is typically conducted during the summer and laboratory work can be conducted throughout the year.  Fieldwork may involve canoeing/boating, mud, bugs, heat, handling animals, and other strenuous dirty-job type work (generally need to be able to lift ~50lbs).  
 For more information about the program and university, see:
 https://indianastate.edu/
https://indianastate.edu/academics/academic-program-finder/biology-phd
https://indianastate.edu/academics/academic-program-finder/biology-ms
  MINIMUM QUALIFICATIONS
 -          For PhD: MS by start date in ecology, biology, zoology, wildlife, or a related/supportive field (Exceptional students with a B.S. may be considered)
-          Minimum undergraduate GPA of 3.0 
-          GRE verbal and quantitative scores of at least 150 are required for PhD applicants that do not yet have a graduate degree or publications.
-          Valid US driver’s license (held for at least 2 years by start date)
-          US citizen or Greencard holder
 Successful applicants will be self-motivated, have a strong interest in wildlife ecology/management and/or related disciplines and possess excellent verbal and written communication skills (including proficiency searching and reviewing peer-reviewed literature).  Prior experience with research, fieldwork, boats/canoes, and common statistical software packages are preferred.  Experience with ecotoxicology/analytical chemistry (e.g., LC-MS/MS), flow-through respirometry/metabolic analysis, GIS, genetic analysis, or other modern analytical techniques/tools that could enhance a graduate project are a plus.
 

APPLICATION INSTRUCTIONS
 Interested applicants should submit the following documents as a single PDF to Dr. Aaron Gooley (aaron.gooley@indstate.edu). Include “Biology PhD Graduate Position - Watersnakes” in the email subject line.
 1. Cover letter summarizing your interest in the position, qualifications, and experience, as well as research interests and career aspirations
2. Curriculum vitae (including GPA and GRE scores if available)
3. Copies of academic transcripts (unofficial are OK)
4. Contact information for 3 professional references
 APPLICATIONS WILL BE REVIEWED AS THEY ARE RECEIVED AND THE POSITION MAY BE FILLED BEFORE THE DEADLINE. THIS TEACHING ASSISTANTISHIP/TUITION WAIVER IS COMPETITIVE WITH OTHER LAB OPENINGS WITIN THE BIOLOGY DEPARTMENT AND POSITIONS ARE LIMITED. 
 APPLICANTS MUST BE PREPARED TO SUBMIT THEIR OFFICIAL APPLICATION TO THE UNIVERSITY (TRANSCRIPTS, GRE SCORES IF REQUIRED, 3 LETTERS OF RECOMMENDATION) IF INSTRUCTED, FOLLOWING A ZOOM INTERVIEW.
 The general steps in the interview/selection process:
1. Initial review of unofficial materials by Dr. Gooley
2. An online interview with Dr. Gooley for select candidates
3. Submission of an official university application if instructed (https://indianastate.edu/apply)
4. Selection by the department’s graduate committee (may involve another online interview with additional faculty)
  Contact
Dr. Aaron Gooley
aaron.gooley@indstate.edu (preferred contact method)

Background
The Forest Forensics and Dendroecology Lab at the University of Wyoming is seeking a M.S. student to study wildfire risk and recovery in Wyoming beginning in Fall 2026. The student will create deep-learning models of fuel loading and regeneration using LiDAR, then organize and execute a field campaign to validate models by sampling forests across the state. The student will join a vibrant team of five graduate students for a collaborative graduate program located in Laramie, WY.
 Benefits and Stipend
This research assistantship is fully funded through the Wyoming Water Research Program and represents a collaboration between the Wyoming Geographic Information Science Center and Wyoming Forest Resilience Initiative. The student will receive a tuition waiver, health insurance, and annual stipend ($23,000 /yr). The start date is August 2026 and expected graduation is May 2028. 
 Required Qualifications
·    BS degree in Forestry, Environmental Science, Biology, or a related field 
·    Demonstrated ability to analyze large datasets with R statistical software 
·    Excellent interpersonal and communication skills 
 Additional Desired Qualifications
·    Experience processing and/or analyzing LiDAR datasets
·    Experience with deep learning and/or machine learning approaches
·    Experience conducting field work in remote settings
·    Experience writing and publishing peer-reviewed manuscripts
_________________________________________________________
 To Apply
Combine the following information into a single PDF file: (1) cover letter describing your research interests, career goals, and qualifications; (2) full CV; (3) unofficial transcripts; (4) email addresses and phone numbers for three professional references. Email to sgermain@uwyo.edu with the subject line: Fire MS Application.

Applications that do not follow these instructions will not be considered
 Application deadline is March 1, 2026

Applications will be reviewed in the order they are received 
Apply now for priority review

Description
*Applications are reviewed on a rolling-basis.

ARS Office/Lab and Location: A research opportunity is currently available with the U.S. Department of Agriculture (USDA), Agricultural Research Service (ARS), located in Parlier, California.

The Agricultural Research Service (ARS) is the U.S. Department of Agriculture's chief scientific in-house research agency with a mission to find solutions to agricultural problems that affect Americans every day from field to table. ARS will deliver cutting-edge, scientific tools and innovative solutions for American farmers, producers, industry, and communities to support the nourishment and well-being of all people; sustain our nation’s agroecosystems and natural resources; and ensure the economic competitiveness and excellence of our agriculture. The vision of the agency is to provide global leadership in agricultural discoveries through scientific excellence.

Research Project: The candidate will conduct data science research on CRIS Research objectives concerning machine learning, image recognition, and prediction of damage to tree nuts from insect pests. They will also collaborate with other team members on statistical analysis of data collected as part of the broader research project, "Innovative Systems-based Approaches to Maintain Commodity Quality and Control Arthropod Pests Important to U.S. Agricultural Production, Trade and Quarantine".

Learning Objectives: Under the guidance of a mentor, the participant will learn:

How to apply forms of artificial intelligence, such as machine learning, to agricultural data sets
How to use generative artificial intelligence to help and improve scientific scholarship
About statistical and data science
About collaborating with a cross-disciplinary scientific team
Mentor(s): The mentor for this opportunity is Charles Burks (charles.burks@usda.gov). If you have questions about the nature of the research, please contact the mentor(s).

Anticipated Appointment Start Date: February 2026. Start date is flexible and will depend on a variety of factors.

Appointment Length: The appointment will initially be for one year, but may be renewed upon recommendation of ARS and is contingent on the availability of funds.

Level of Participation: The appointment is full time.

Participant Stipend: The participant will receive a monthly stipend commensurate with educational level and experience. The anticipated stipend range is $5,000 - $5,120 monthly.

Citizenship Requirements: This opportunity is available to U.S. citizens only.

ORISE Information: This program, administered by ORAU through its contract with the U.S. Department of Energy (DOE) to manage the Oak Ridge Institute for Science and Education (ORISE), was established through an interagency agreement between DOE and ARS. Participants do not become employees of USDA, ARS, DOE or the program administrator, and there are no employment-related benefits. Proof of health insurance is required for participation in this program. Health insurance can be obtained through ORISE.

Questions: Please visit our Program Website. After reading, if you have additional questions about the application process, please email ORISE.ARS.PacificWest@orau.org and include the reference code for this opportunity.

Qualifications
The qualified candidate should have received a master's degree in one of the relevant fields. Degree must have been received within the past four years.

Stipend
$5,000.00 – $5,120.00 Monthly

USDA-ARS-PWA-2026-0057

Description
 Title: Graduate Research Assistant – M.Sc. in Forest Recourses, emphasis in Wildlife Management 
Affiliation: Snowden Waterfowl Center of Excellence, University of Arkansas at Monticello 
Location: Monticello, Arkansas 
Start date: May or August 2026 
Available funding – up to 3 years 
 Position Description: The Snowden Waterfowl Center of Excellence within the College of forestry, Agriculture, and Natural Resources at the University of Arkansas at Monticello is recruiting applicants for the position of Graduate Research Assistant (GRA) to pursue a Master’s of Science (M.Sc.) degree in Forest Resources studying the spatial arrangement of habitat components including bottomland hardwood reforestation on habitat suitability for midcontinent mallards. Specific aspects of the study will include the construction of a user-friendly, ArcGIS online decision support tool for prioritizing areas for reforestation that will maximize co-benefits for waterfowl. The position carries an annual stipend of $20,000 plus tuition waiver. Expected start date of May or August 2026. 
 Project Description: Bottomland hardwood forests are under extreme and accelerated pressure from anthropogenic and environmental stressors, subsequently impact many ecological processes including the degradation of habitat quality for forested wetland dependent waterfowl. The extent of historical loss from drainage and agricultural conversion; degradation of forest health from insects and disease; shifts in tree species composition from water stress, and excessive declines in abundance of wintering waterfowl in the Mississippi Alluvial Valley are overwhelmingly documented. Thus, restoration and reforestation effects are of utmost priority in the region and newly emerging carbon credit markets may provide the catalyst needed to accelerate reforestation in the region to improve habitat suitability for wintering mallards. The purpose of this project is to provide guidance for carbon-based reforestation efforts to maximize the co-benefits for waterfowl.   
 Requirements: Applicants must have a 2.7 overall undergraduate GPA or 3.0 GPA in the last 60 semester hours of undergraduate courses. Also required a B.S. degree in geospatial sciences, geography, wildlife management/conservation, or related field, while experiences with waterfowl, GIS, remote sensing, data science, and landscape ecology are preferred. Applicants must have a valid U.S. driver’s license or obtain the same within 60 days of starting employment. Overnight travel and fall/winter field work are required as well as the ability to work outdoors in all weather conditions. 
 Location and Facilities: The Snowden Waterfowl Center of Excellence is housed within the College of Forestry, Agriculture & Natural Resources at the University of Arkansas at Monticello, in southeastern Arkansas. Graduate students will have a designated office space and computer, and will work alongside faculty, staff, and other graduate students within the Snowden Waterfowl Center and College of Forestry, Agriculture & Natural Resources. 
 Application & Additional Information: Please send cover letter, CV or resume, and list of professional references to Dr. Douglas Osborne by email at osborne@uamont.edu. Specify "BLH Mallard Assistantship" in the subject line of the email. 
Contact
Dr. Douglas Osborne
8704601448
osborne@uamont.edu (preferred contact method)

Title: Graduate Research Assistant – M.Sc. in Forest Recourses, emphasis in Wildlife Management 
Affiliation: Snowden Waterfowl Center of Excellence, University of Arkansas at Monticello 
Location: Monticello, Arkansas
Start date: May or August 2026
Available funding – up to 3 years 
 Position Description: The Snowden Waterfowl Center of Excellence within the College of forestry, Agriculture, and Natural Resources at the University of Arkansas at Monticello is in search of applicants for a Graduate Research Assistant (GRA) to pursue a Master’s of Science (M.Sc.) degree studying the migration ecology of green-winged teal. Specific aspects of the study could include spring migration chronology and stop-over habitat selection, breeding settlement patterns, and winter site fidelity of transmitter-marked female green-winged teal that winter in the Red River Valley region of NW Louisiana and SW Arkansas. The position carries an annual stipend of $20,000 plus tuition waiver. Expected start date of May or August 2026.
 Project Description: Green-winged teal are among the most harvest species of dabbling duck in the Mississippi and Central Flyways, however little has been documented of their migration chronology, habitat use, cross-season effects on breeding location, and rate of site fidelity during the annual cycle. This project aims to evaluate the general migration ecology of the species, with some flexibility in objectives that can be defined by the incoming student. 
 Requirements: Applicants must have a 2.7 overall undergraduate GPA or 3.0 GPA in the last 60 semester hours of undergraduate courses. Also required a B.S. degree in geospatial sciences, geography, wildlife management/conservation, zoology, or related field, while experiences with GIS, remote sensing, data science, landscape ecology and waterfowl are preferred. Applicants must have a valid U.S. driver’s license or obtain the same within 60 days of starting employment. Overnight travel and fall/winter field work are required as well as the ability to work outdoors in all weather conditions. 
 Location and Facilities: The Snowden Waterfowl Center of Excellence is housed within the College of Forestry, Agriculture & Natural Resources at the University of Arkansas at Monticello, in southeastern Arkansas. Graduate students will have a designated office space and computer, and will work alongside faculty, staff, and other graduate students within the Snowden Waterfowl Center and College of Forestry, Agriculture & Natural Resources.
 Application & Additional Information: Please send cover letter, CV or resume, and list of professional references to Dr. Douglas Osborne by email at osborne@uamont.edu. Specify AGWT Assistantship in the subject line of the email.

Position Overview The Road to Recovery (R2R) initiative is dedicated to reversing widespread declines in bird populations across North America. Following the publication of Rosenberg et al. (2019) documenting these declines, R2R partners have worked collaboratively to advance science, influence policy, engage the public, and mobilize resources to recover bird populations. R2R seeks a motivated graduate student (PhD or masters) to serve as a Graduate Fellow. This part-time position provides hands-on experience in bird conservation coordination, science communication, community building, and program administration. Applicants from diverse backgrounds and lived experiences are strongly encouraged to apply. All applicants should share a passion for bird conservation. 

View details here: https://r2rbirds.org/wp-content/uploads/2026/01/Road-to-Recovery-Graduate-Fellow-Posting-2026.pdf

ABOUT UNIVERSITY OF IDAHO—MCCALL FIELD CAMPUS 

The mission of the McCall FIELD CAMPUS AND OUTDOOR SCIENCE SCHOOL is to transform individuals and communities through innovative research and educational experiences. We envision vibrant, diverse and inclusive communities, empowered to ask difficult questions and transform ways of thinking, to collaboratively and compassionately sustain the social and ecological systems that provide for us.  
 Our faculty, staff and students value creativity, sustainability, diversity, inclusion, integrity, collaboration and reflection. To this end, we educate, lead, discover, create and communicate. 
 Requirements for Application 
Statement of purpose titled "The McCall Outdoor Science School" that addresses the following prompt: 
This immersive graduate experience is academically rigorous and compressed into a short timeframe. Graduate work requires independent and collaborative problem-solving, creativity, and willingness to learn and struggle, often in the face of uncertainty. Students will be members of a professional learning community that collaborates with peers, K12 students, and teachers, faculty, and staff. It often requires long hours and significant intellectual as well as emotional labor. In a one-page essay, please describe how your experiences, skills, and motivations will help you to thrive in this graduate program. 
Three letters of recommendation will be required to complete your application packet. On the online application, you will be prompted to enter names and contact information for three references. These three people will be sent requests for a letter of recommendation from the University and will send those back directly. 
Official Transcripts/ academic credentials. These must be the official version from your University or College. You can upload into the application or mail them to: 
Graduate Admissions 
University of Idaho 875 
Perimeter Drive MS 3019 
Moscow, ID 83844-3019 
GRE not required 
Contact
Leslie Dorsey
2088851080
ldorsey@uidaho.edu (preferred contact method)

title: Mesocarnivore Graduate Assistantship (MS), Colorado State University
description:
Mesocarnivore Graduate Assistantship (MS), Colorado State University
Colorado State University (State) | https://colostate.edu
Details
Application Deadline:
03/05/2026
Published:
01/28/2026
Starting Date:
before 8/24/2026
Ending Date:
before 6/1/2029
Hours per Week:
20 - 40
Salary:
$3,000 per month
Education Required:
Bachelors
Experience Required:
at least 1 year
Location:
Fort Collins, Colorado
Tags:
Graduate Opportunities
Description
A graduate assistantship for a master’s student is expected to be funded at Colorado State University (Fort Collins, CO) working with Dr. Brian D. Gerber (https://bgerber123.github.io/) at the Colorado Cooperative Fish and Wildlife Research Unit and wildlife researchers at Colorado Parks and Wildlife. The funding will be a mixture of graduate research and teaching assistantships covering university tuition, fees, health coverage, and includes a pre-tax monthly pay of $3000/month. The position is expected to start Fall 2026 and be funded through Spring 2029.

The student will be expected to develop a project proposal in the first year that includes a sampling frame that will be used to guide field surveys that they lead. The focus of this study will be to better understand mesocarnivore distribution and habitat associations throughout the state of Colorado; priority species are gray fox and ring-tailed cats, and secondarily bobcat, American hog-nosed skunk, and the western spotted skunk. Surveys will be focused on deploying camera traps primarily within two summer field seasons. Results from this work will inform efforts by Colorado Parks and Wildlife to conserve and manage the populations of these species.

Preferred Qualifications: 
-          Experience leading field crews and managing logistical operations
-          Experience with deploying camera traps

Minimum Qualifications:
-          A Bachelor of Science degree in wildlife ecology, biology, natural resource management, or related field
-          A year or more of wildlife related field work experience
-          Desire to learn to plan, execute, and lead a field study from conception to scientific publication
-          Experience navigating safely through rugged environments (hiking and driving)  
-          Strong work ethic 
-          Desire to learn or expand on coding and statistical modeling knowledge and skills
-          Desire to collaborate with state wildlife management agencies

To apply, please send the following materials via email with “MS mesocarnivore” as the subject line to Dr. Brian D. Gerber (brian.gerber@colostate.edu) by March 1, 2026: 1) Cover letter outlining career goals, academic interests, and relevant experience related to the minimum and preferred qualifications, 2) resume with contact information for 3-4 personal references, and unofficial copy of B.S. transcripts. 

Contact
Brian Gerber
brian.gerber@colostate.edu (preferred contact method)

M.S. Research Assistantship - Stream Restoration
North Dakota State University (State) | http://www.travisseaborn.com
Details

Location:
North Dakota State University (Fargo, North Dakota)
Tags:
Graduate Opportunities
Description
M.S. Opportunity: Riparian restoration tools in working grasslands
The Genomics, Ecology, and Modeling for Conservation Lab at North Dakota State University, led by Travis Seaborn, is recruiting for one M.S. position to join our team working on a recently funded project in collaboration with the Albert K. Ekre Grassland Preserve. For more information on the preserve see: https://ndsufoundation.com/magazine/2021/09/ekre-grassland-preserve. 
 Anticipated start date: Summer 2026. Stiped ~$25,000 for 2-3 years. Tuition waiver also provided.
 The overall project will advance our ability to understand community responses to riparian restoration. Riparian ecosystems in the Northern Great Plains have been heavily altered by anthropogenic activities. Although there are numerous restoration options for riparian ecosystems, a common and effective restoration practice, in particular in incised stream systems, are beaver dam analogs. Using streams at the Ekre Grassland Preserve and nearby public land, we will be looking to do a restoration project using invasive buckthorn woody materials. To achieve this, we are beginning to plan a Before-After-Control-Impact design to assess riparian and floodplain ecosystem responses, including geomorphology, biological community, and water quality. Much of the beaver dam analog research that has been done has occurred in the western United States, and response to these activities in the Northern Great Plains is unknown. Surveys of the biological community may include electrofishing and minnow trapping for fish, camera traps for mammals, visual and auditory surveys for birds, and plant identification along transects.
 The primary goals of this position include:
1.    Identify the impact of beaver dam analogs.
2.    Using geographic information systems, develop beaver species distribution models for the region.
 To apply: Please email travis.seaborn@ndsu.edu a letter of interest, which should include an explanation of fit and past relevant experience, and CV by February 20th.
Contact
Travis Seaborn
2537973130
travis.seaborn@ndsu.edu (preferred contact method)

title: USDA-ARS Research Fellowship in Behavioral Pest Management for Vegetable Crops
description:
USDA-ARS Research Fellowship in Behavioral Pest Management for Vegetable Crops
Oak Ridge Associated Universities (ORAU) (Private) | https://orise.orau.gov/index.html
Details
Posting:
https://www.zintellect.com/Opportunity/Details/USDA-ARS-NEA-2026-0028
Application Deadline:
03/27/2026
Published:
01/27/2026
Starting Date:
after 2/2/2026
Hours per Week:
at least 40
Salary:
Commensurate / Negotiable
Education Required:
Some Undergraduate
Experience Required:
none
Location:
Beltsville, Maryland
Tags:
Graduate Opportunities
Undergraduate Opportunities
Description
 *Applications are reviewed on a rolling-basis.

ARS Office/Lab and Location: A research opportunity is currently available with the U.S. Department of Agriculture (USDA), Agricultural Research Service (ARS), located in Beltsville, Maryland.

The Agricultural Research Service (ARS) is the U.S. Department of Agriculture's chief scientific in-house research agency with a mission to find solutions to agricultural problems that affect Americans every day from field to table. ARS will deliver cutting-edge, scientific tools and innovative solutions for American farmers, producers, industry, and communities to support the nourishment and well-being of all people; sustain our nation’s agroecosystems and natural resources; and ensure the economic competitiveness and excellence of our agriculture. The vision of the agency is to provide global leadership in agricultural discoveries through scientific excellence.

Research Project: This project aims to investigate behavioral control of vegetable pests to advance sustainable pest management and safeguard crop productivity of vegetable crops in the US. The fellow will sample, evaluate, and collect field populations, and maintain laboratory colonies to investigate attraction of key pest species to candidate attractants, including pheromones. Using field and laboratory bioassays, fellow will gain experience by conducting research on the biology, ecology and behavior of beetles and true bugs, and their impact on vegetable crops including squash and potato.  Areas of research include chemical ecology, insect behavior and integrated pest management.  Under the guidance of a mentor, the fellow will conduct research in both laboratory and field settings and also participate in multi-institutional team-based research efforts. The project will evaluate various attractants and combinations with traps and other pest management tactics, to determine effective outcomes for pest management. Results will be disseminated through peer-reviewed publications, stakeholder reports, and annual progress updates, directly supporting improved opportunities for effective pest management strategies and strengthening agricultural resilience.

Learning Objectives: Under the guidance of a mentor, the participant will learn about and gain experience in:

Conducting and testing insect rearing methods and behavioral bioassays. 
Conducting laboratory and field research aimed at developing sustainable management tactics for agricultural pests.
Conducting chemical ecology studies to identify potential attractants or repellents.
Collaborating effectively within a multidisciplinary, multi-institutional team.
Performing statistical analyses and reporting related scientific findings.
Mentor(s): The mentor for this opportunity is Donald C. Weber (don.weber@usda.gov). If you have questions about the nature of the research, please contact the mentor(s).

Anticipated Appointment Start Date: February 2, 2026. Start date is flexible and will depend on a variety of factors.

Appointment Length: The appointment will initially be for one year, but may be renewed upon recommendation of ARS and is contingent on the availability of funds.

Level of Participation: The appointment is full time.

Participant Stipend: The participant will receive a monthly stipend commensurate with educational level and experience. The anticipated stipend range is $45,000 - $60,000 annually.

Citizenship Requirements: This opportunity is available to U.S. citizens only.

ORISE Information: This program, administered by ORAU through its contract with the U.S. Department of Energy (DOE) to manage the Oak Ridge Institute for Science and Education (ORISE), was established through an interagency agreement between DOE and ARS. Participants do not become employees of USDA, ARS, DOE or the program administrator, and there are no employment-related benefits. Proof of health insurance is required for participation in this program. Health insurance can be obtained through ORISE.

Questions: Please visit our Program Website. After reading, if you have additional questions about the application process, please email ORISE.ARS.Northeast@orau.org and include the reference code for this opportunity.

Qualifications
The qualified candidate should have received or be currently pursuing a bachelor's or master's degree in one of the relevant fields.

Preferred skills:

Experience with field research experiments, especially in agriculture, and handling and rearing of insects is very desirable.
Stipend

Description
The Microbial Ecology Lab at the University of Texas at San Antonio is accepting applications for a post-gradate research associate to join our group in the Department of Biology, Health, and the Environment. The position start date is summer 2026.
 The applicant will be working with Dr. Allison Veach and other collaborators through the United States Department of Agriculture Natural Resources Conservation Service (USDA-NRCS) in San Antonio, Texas USA with field sites spanning urban - rangeland - grasslands in central Texas. Project goals are to use novel, field-based methods to identify fungal and bacterial biomass across soils and relate field counts to validated laboratory estimates. The applicant will lead microscopy research to estimate fungal hyphae in soil, collaborate with other graduate and undergraduate researchers, and provide oversight in laboratory maintenance. This position includes 20% time lab management and 80% research.
 This position is funded for 1 year and can be extended into 2 years based on performance. Health care and benefits are included. UTSA is a public research university and a Hispanic-Serving Institution located in northwest San Antonio. The main campus, where this position will be housed, enrolls ~35,000 students, has a diverse set of faculty and students in environmental science, microbiology and microbial ecology, geosciences, and ecology.
 Qualifications: 
·       Master’s degree in Biology, Ecology, or similar discipline. PhD is preferred but not required.
·       Experience with microscopy and working with soils
·       Additional laboratory experience in molecular biology
·       Strong writing and communication skills
 Application Process: Please email a compiled PDF that includes (1) a cover letter highlighting applicants interest and experiences, (2) CV and (3) three names of profession references to Dr. Allison Veach at allison.veach@utsa.edu. Review of applications will begin immediately and remain open until the position is filled. Please contact Dr. Veach with any questions pertaining to this position.
Contact
Allison Veach
allison.veach@utsa.edu (preferred contact method)

title: Adaptation/Hydrology/Construction Management Fellowship
description:
Adaptation/Hydrology/Construction Management Fellowship
MobilizeGreen (Private) | http://mobilizegreen.org
Details
Posting:
https://mobilizegreen.bamboohr.com/careers/910
Application Deadline:
05/31/2026
Published:
01/22/2026
Starting Date:
after 6/22/2026
Ending Date:
after 12/18/2026
Hours per Week:
40
Salary:
$800 per week
Education Required:
Bachelors
Experience Required:
none
Location:
Washington, D.C.
Tags:
Graduate Opportunities
Undergraduate Opportunities
Description
Join us. Do work that matters!

In partnership with the US Fish & Wildlife Service, MobilizeGreen seeks Adaptation Fellows working on adaptation, hydrology, and/or construction management for the U.S. Fish & Wildlife Service. In general, Adaptation Fellows will support the Service’s goal of adapting to and mitigating contemporary ecological change by working collaboratively with partners, integrating nature-based solutions, and helping to infuse adaptation and resilience throughout management of Service trust resources.

This fellowship will be focused on adaptation, hydrology, and/or construction management. As a fellow, you will support efforts to adapt to rapid ecological change, restore habitat and hydrology, and maintain infrastructure on National Wildlife Refuge System lands. You will visit beautiful settings and engage in nature-based restoration projects, hydrologic and geomorphologic data collection and analysis, contract administration, construction oversight, and stakeholder collaboration.

Fellows will assist with infrastructure planning and inspection, technical engineering, and creating communication tools to promote adaptation and infrastructure maintenance. This position provides a unique opportunity to collaborate with multiple USFWS programs, including Refuges, Ecological Services, Science Applications, Fisheries, and the Partners for Fish and Wildlife Program. As a fellow, you will develop skills in hydrology, project management, and restoration science. This fellowship is designed for early-career professionals interested in adaptation and resilience, hydrology, construction management, and infrastructure maintenance.

Duty Station and Location: Positions for the 2026 Maintenance and Infrastructure Fellowship Program (MIFP) cohort will be located at FWS refuges and offices across the country:
San Luis Valley NWR Complex - Alamosa, CO
Check out all open fellowship positions here

Term: 26 weeks (6 months), full-time (40 hours per week), on-site position. The fellowship is eligible for extension up to 3 years (36 months).

Anticipated Start Date: June 2026

Benefits:
Hands on learning and job training experience
Paid orientation and travel to orientation
Mentorship for career and professional development
Weekly living allowance ($800 per week)
Housing
Relocation assistance (if applicable)
Health insurance option
Public Lands Corps hiring eligibility (with successful completion of fellowship). Other authorities may apply.

Position Duties:

Specific Tasks Required May Include:
Fieldwork and Hydrology:
Installing and maintaining hydrologic monitoring equipment (e.g., staff gages, shallow groundwater wells, and water level recorders).
Conduct water quality sampling
Conducting topographic and bathymetric surveys
Monitoring vegetation, elevation, and hydrology using established protocols and synthesizing data to assess project success
Adaptation:
Work as part of a Team to restore hydrology to salt marsh, freshwater wetlands, or other habitats depending on location.
Facilitating cross-programmatic coordination to advance priority resiliency projects.
Developing communication materials, and demonstration case studies to disseminate restoration methodology, and assist other projects.
Preparing briefing materials and innovative content to communicate adaptation success stories.
Supporting feasibility, design, and implementation of conservation projects that enhance ecological resilience.
Construction and Engineering Support:
Conducting site condition analyses, data collection, and instrumentation data analysis.
Performing limited engineering schematics or architectural designs for developmental assignments.
Participating in inspections, reviews, and evaluations of facilities and infrastructure.
Assisting with project management, contract administration, compliance checks, and database operations.
Using remote sensing tools and data analysis software, to support project designs.
Preparing drawings, permits, material testing, and documentation for projects.

Specific Tasks and Learning Goals:
Gain skills in hydrology, geomorphology, and nature-based restoration design, including data collection, analysis, and project design.
Develop expertise in surface water and groundwater monitoring, surveying, and tidal flow assessment.
Acquire knowledge of construction management techniques, project management of in-house and contracted crew, and compliance reporting for a large-scale, multiple year restoration project.
Understand how to integrate adaptation and nature-based engineering principles into wildlife conservation and infrastructure projects.
Build professional networks across USFWS, working with various stakeholders including contractors, States, Tribes, NGOs, and local governments.
Develop case studies, communication materials, intranet content, and other shared learning materials to promote the operationalization of science-based action.
Experience cross-programmatic collaboration, project management, and collaborative team-based field operations.

Qualifications/Skills and Knowledge:

Required:
Degree or coursework in environmental science, natural resources, environmental or adaptation science, hydrology, engineering, geoscience, biology, construction management, or related fields.
Strong analytical, organizational, interpersonal, and problem-solving skills.
Effective communication, teamwork, and independent work skills.
Willingness to work outdoors in varying conditions and conduct physical tasks.
Ages 18-30 (or up to 35 for veterans).
Valid driver’s license.
U.S. Citizen or Permanent Resident.


Preferred:
Knowledge of hydrologic monitoring, land surveying techniques, and construction management tools. 
Experience with GIS, data analysis, and nature-based solutions.
Familiarity with public lands management, environmental policy, and engineering practices.
Demonstrated ability to develop case studies, technical materials, and success stories for different kinds of audiences.
Effective written and verbal communication skills.
Desire to drive adaptation and engineering solutions collaboratively.
Knowledge and proficiency in operating and maintaining small-engine equipment.

Specific Requirements/Preferences:
Physical Requirements: Work involves both office and field tasks, with activities such as walking on rough terrain, carrying equipment (up to 40 lbs) over long distances, and working in variable weather conditions.
Position Environment: Duties are performed indoors and outdoors, often requiring travel to remote sites and exposure to temperature extremes, biting insects, ticks, and poison ivy.

For more information on MobilizeGreen go to: www.mobilizegreen.org
Contact
MobilizeGreen

title: MS Assistantship: Understanding how cattle foraging behavior influences weight gain in Central Arizona
description:
MS Assistantship: Understanding how cattle foraging behavior influences weight gain in Central Arizona
University of Arizona (State) | https://www.arizona.edu/
Details
Application Deadline:
04/30/2026
Published:
01/20/2026
Starting Date:
after 8/1/2026
Hours per Week:
at least 40
Salary:
starting at $27,500 per year
Education Required:
Bachelors
Experience Required:
none
Locations:
Tucson, Arizona
Rimrock, Arizona
Tags:
Graduate Opportunities
Description
Project Background: 

We are hiring an MS student to examine whether foraging behavior metrics, like grazing bout duration and velocity while grazing, predict diet quality and average daily weight gain of beef cows on central Arizona rangelands. This region contains a wealth of native biodiversity with ecosystems ranging from mixed desert scrub, pinyon-juniper woodlands, and high-elevation ponderosa pine forest. The student will be co-advised by Drs. Jacob Hennig and Flavie Audoin and will be enrolled in the Ecology, Management, and Restoration of Rangelands program within the School of Natural Resources & the Environment (https://snre.arizona.edu/). Funding is available for 2 years and includes salary, tuition, and health insurance. The student will be based in Tucson, AZ but will conduct field work at the University of Arizona V-V Ranch near Rimrock, AZ. Tasks will consist of attaching GPS ear tags to cattle, conducting field behavioral observations, collecting fecal samples, and analysis of movement data. 

The University of Arizona is the state’s land grant university, located in Tucson, Arizona. The University of Arizona is on the land and territories of many Indigenous peoples; today, Arizona is home to 22 federally recognized tribes, with Tucson being home to the O’odham and the Yaqui.

Required Qualifications: 
·       B.S. in rangeland ecology, animal science, ecology, or a related discipline 
·       A valid US driver’s license 
·       Proficiency in English 

Preferred Qualifications: 
·       Prior experience with livestock handling 
·       Ability to operate 4x4 vehicles 
·       Experience driving and navigating in rugged and remote terrain 
·       Demonstrated written, verbal, and quantitative skills 
·       Field data collection experience 
·       Experience with data management, statistical analysis, and the R programming language 
·       Strong interpersonal skills, with demonstrated ability to work long hours independently and in teams under challenging conditions 
·       Willingness for frequent travel 

To apply, please submit application materials (CV, contact information for 3 professional references, unofficial transcripts, and a cover letter describing interest in the project and career goals) to jhennig@arizona.edu and faudoin@arizona.edu. The GRE is not required for admission or to work with our team, but applicants may also include GRE scores if they think it will improve their packet.  

Contact
Jacob Hennig
jhennig@arizona.edu (preferred contact method)

description:
USDA-ARS Postgraduate Fellowship in Rice Utilization and Cancer Prevention
Oak Ridge Associated Universities (ORAU) (Private) | https://orise.orau.gov/index.html
Details

https://www.zintellect.com/Opportunity/Details/USDA-ARS-SEA-2026-0025
